description:
Candidatus Walczuchella endosymbiont of Icerya purchasi is a bacterial endosymbiont that resides within the body of the cottony cushion scale insect, Icerya purchasi. It is a member of the phylum Bacteroidetes and is classified as a "Candidatus" species, meaning it has not yet been formally described and named according to the International Code of Nomenclature of Bacteria.

This endosymbiont is believed to play a crucial role in the nutritional ecology of its host, the cottony cushion scale insect. Icerya purchasi is a sap-feeding insect that feeds on various plants, and the Candidatus Walczuchella endosymbiont is thought to provide its host with essential nutrients, such as vitamins and amino acids, that may be lacking in the plant sap diet.

The presence of this endosymbiont has been detected through molecular techniques, such as 16S rRNA gene sequencing, and its genome has been partially characterized, revealing insights into its metabolic capabilities and potential symbiotic functions. However, further research is needed to fully understand the specific nature of the relationship between Candidatus Walczuchella and its Icerya purchasi host, as well as the broader ecological implications of this endosymbiotic association.
